Merging in the debug replay branch. This tool is super useful and I love it
I've also made some bugfixes and reorganizations on this branch and I realized I needed to get those in. Basically, Nova was creating a new staging buffer and a new command buffer every time a texture was updated, and was creating a new command buffer each frame. These things by themselves were just kinda silly and not awful, but the fact that Nova was destroying these things meant it had to use fences to wait for the command buffers to finish executing, which lead to a GPU deadlock and a timeout. This no longer happens in the debug replay tool.
I also made GUI geometry follow the same code path as chunk geometry. This let me put the geometry updates at the beginning of the frame, which removed a VkWaitForFence call - furthering my goal of removing fences
Finally, I added a preprocessor definition DUMP_NOVA_CALLS which enables the debug dumping. The CMake file enables this for regular Nova but disables it for the debug replay. This paves the way for not having to copy the debug dump file, but I didn't make that change.

This is a monster PR. 75 commits. In an effort to make this readable, I have split this into commits by change type. A brief guide for reviewing this:

Commits starting with clang-tidy: are a direct result of the named clang-tidy check. There is no more than one of these checks per commit.
The commits names THICC: Apply automatic clang-tidy-fixes and reformat are very large, programmatic changes. These should most likely be skimmed, as reading the entire thing will bore you to death. If there is a problem with formatting, that is outside of the scope of this PR.
Windows is broken. It will be fixed shortly. Windows headers are extremely include order sensitive.

Major Changes:

Added format reformat, lint, lint-by-file, lint-by-diagnostic, and lint-fix targets.
Boosted warnings up to -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wconversion -Werror
Added fmtlib for formatting. Full integration of fmtlib comes later.
Moved gtest into 3rd party folder to prevent warning fall through.
Automatic build failure on lack of formatting or warnings from any compiler.

Adds in UBOs. Yay!
uniform_buffer_object is a dumb UBO. You give it some data, it uploads the data, big whoop.
auto_buffer is a large buffer that allocates itself into smaller bits. Original use case is allocating space on the GPU for model matrices for render objects, but I expect it'll get used a lot more in the future
I also moved the whole renderer from namespace nova to namespace nova::renderer. This will help us keep the renderer contained when Nova gets developed into a full engine
I tweaked the clang-tidy settings to remove the warning about using auto. auto is fine sometimes but I really don't like it. I come to C++ for explicit types!

Render things!
This PR adds the notion of a renderable. A renderable is any object that can be rendered. Currently only static meshes are supported
Renderables are automatically batched according to their render pass, material, and mesh - e.g. Nova automatically instances multiple renderables that use the same material pass and mesh. Future work will likely instance across materials, but that's not supported yet
I also removed the megamesh buffer and the indirect rendering because that caused my OS to crash. Meshes now have their own buffers, because it's simpler. I may go back to putting multiple meshes in the same buffer - but honestly I don't see much value at this point, since the buffers would have to be organized by renderpass and material pass and that's a lot of complexity

I also removed the megamesh buffer and the indirect rendering because that caused my OS to crash. Meshes now have their own buffers, because it's simpler. I may go back to putting multiple meshes in the same buffer - but honestly I don't see much value at this point, since the buffers would have to be organized by renderpass and material pass and that's a lot of complexity

column20:
In Nova, all the model matrices are stored in one large model matrix buffer
May or may not eventually switch to an instance-rate vertex buffer, but that's a separate issue
When recording drawcalls, the old code would write model matrices to the model matrix buffer by starting each material at index 0. This meant each material's model matrices would overwrite the previous materials' model matrices. This change moves from a local index to a global one, so each successive material writes to a new index
There are come considerations for when Nova becomes threaded, these are expressed in the comments this PR adds

column20:
I've added a procedural mesh class. This allows one to upload new mesh data every frame, facilitating highly dynamic geometry
Currently ProceduralMesh uploads its data every frame. This is probably fine, but future work will profile and optimize so mesh data isn't uploaded unless needed
Procedural Meshes are owned by NovaRenderer. I created MapAccessor as a way to access an object in a map without knowing the map itself. This allows code external to NovaRenderer to set the mesh data of a procedural mesh
I've also renamed a few things to better match how the current code works - for instance, "renderable" is becoming "render command", and "render engine" is starting to become "render device" - although render device will be a separate PR
Finally, the frame index that a Swapchain returns is now a uint8_t. This better reflects that there will only ever be a small number of in-flight frames at a given time
Closes #223

Some major changes I remember off the top of my head:

Renderpacks only supply the rendergraph for the 3D scene. The host application supplies the render graph for the UI. Nova itself has some tasks that run before the 3D scene or UI, and some tasks the run after the 3D scene and UI

Nova uses shader reflection to get the vertex data layout for each pipeline. There's an assumption that the host application will provide mesh data in the correct format, but I don't have any validation for this assumption
Mesh data is now a void* to the vertex data and a void* to the index data. Nova no longer defines anything about the vertex format, so don't fuck up your vertices
Better C++ API for creating renderpasses and pipelines, which Nova uses to make the render pass to layer the UI on top of the 3D scene
RHI pipeline create info struct that's separate from the renderpack pipeline data struct. The RHI struct has all the data a pipeline needs, and some data that Nova doesn't use yet, while the renderpack struct is more user-friendly and a little higher level
Got minitrace working and added some minitrace events to a few places in the code. A future PR will add in more profiling
Lots of updates to rex::core as graphite developed new features and fixed bugs
Switch from custom GPU memory allocators to VulkanMemoryAllocator

column13: Refactor renderpasses into SceneRenderpass and GlobalRenderpass
column20:
I've done a refactor
Previously, there was just one renderpass type. It was kinda cool I guess - but not cool enough
Now there's multiple types
SceneRenderpass is a renderpass over scene objects. It uses the bindless material system to access material parameters and textures, and it uses the standard pipeline system to render a bunch of meshes
GlobalRenderpass is a renderpass that operates "globally" - that is, it doesn't handle any objects in the scene. Intended use case is post-processing effects, or merging together the UI and scene output render targets. They use more bespoke code, typically using a RhiResourceBinder to bind resources to a pipeline
Of course, you can still create a renderpass that doesn't follow either of these paradigms. The UI renderpass is just that
What is a RhIResourceBinder? It's an abstraction for binding resources to pipelines. The Vulkan implementation performs shader reflection on a pipeline to extract the descriptor sets the pipelines uses, then creates VkDescriptorSetLayouts and a VkPipelineLayout to bind descriptor sets to that pipeline, and creates VkDescriptorSets to actually represent the resources to the GPU. You can change bound resources at any time, and the descriptor sets won't be updated until the next time you bind a RhiResourceBinder to a command list
I've also split the concept of a pipeline in two - surface pipelines and global pipelines. Surface pipelines draw objects in the scene using bindless materials, global pipelines are executed by a GlobalRenderpass over the whole scene. Currently all pipelines loaded from a renderpack are surface pipelines - a future PR will give renderpack pipelines a way to say if they're surface or global
That's the long and the short of it
